person_039.name: JohnWoodward
person_039.description: Natural philospher with an interest in geology. His collection of fossils and minerals is part of Cambridge University's Sedgwick Museum of Geology. FRSL.

person_040.name: Jean HenriHassenfratz
person_040.description: First Professor of Physics at the École polytechnique, Paris, and mine inspector.

person_016.name: JosephPriestley
person_016.description: Unitarian and political radical forced into exile in Pennsylvania. As a natural philospher and chemist who retained belief in phlogiston, he discovered oxygen and nitrous oxide though not under those names. FRSL.

person_041.name: JohnBillingsley
person_041.description: Wrote the Somerset volume for the Board of Agriculture county surveys. A founder of the Bath and West of England Society of which Davy was elected an honorary member in 1804.

person_042.name: AllanMaconochie
person_042.description: Lord Meadowbank from 1796. Scottish advocate and a founder of the Royal Society of Edinburgh.

person_044.name: ArthurYoung
person_044.description: Agricultural writer and Secretary to the Board of Agriculture. FRSL.

person_046.name: JamesCooke
person_046.description: Cooke or Cook. Anglican minister of Ardwick (near Manchester). Author of Drill Husbandry Perfected.

person_047.name: Robert WIlliamesVaughan
person_047.description: Welsh landowner, second baronet and Tory MP for Merioneth, 1792-1836. Davy seems to have stayed with him in the summer of 1805.

person_048.name: Nicolas-Théodore deSaussure
person_048.description: Swiss chemist and student of plant physiology who made seminal advances in phytochemistry. ForMemRSL.

person_045.name: AndrewCoventry
person_045.description: First Professor of Agriculture at the University of Edinburgh from 1790 until death.

person_049.name: Louis BernardGuyton de Morveau
person_049.description: French chemist and revolutionary politician who is credited with producing the first systematic method of chemical nomenclature. ForMemRSL.

person_050.name: Louis NicolasVauquelin
person_050.description: French pharmacist and chemist who met Davy in Paris in 1813. ForMemRSL.

person_051.name: JohnPringle
person_051.description: Physician who served as President of the Royal Society of London, 1772-1778. Created a baronet. FRSL.

person_053.name: RichardWatson
person_053.description: Professor of Chemisty at Cambridge University, 1764-1773 and Bishop of Llandaff , 1782-1816. FRSL

person_052.name: GeorgePearson
person_052.description: Physician and chemist who introduced a new systematic nomenclature for inorganic chemistry in English based on that devised by French chemists and confirmed the effacy of vaccination. FRSL.

person_054.name: Charles WilliamBury
person_054.description: Irish landowner and politician, 1st Earl of Charleville from 1806. Was connected to both the Royal Institution and the Board of Agriculture. FRSL.

person_248.name: CharlesDundas
person_248.description: Scottish born politician who sat for a number of seats. Created Baron Amesbury just before his death, he was involved with the Board of Agriculture.

person_056.name: WilliamMontagu
person_056.description: From 1788 fifth Duke of Manchester. Army officer, Ordinary Member of the Board of Agriculture and later Governor of Jamacia. Davy cited his agricultural work in Elements of Agricultural Chemistry

person_057.name: John BakerHolroyd
person_057.description: Independent-minded MP; from 1802 1st Baron Sheffield and from 1816 1st Earl of Sheffield. President of the Board of Agriculture, 1802-1806. During autumn 1803 Davy stayed with him for three weeks at his Sussex seat, Sheffield Place. FRSL.

place_017.name: Roehampton
place_017.description: Roehampton is an area in south-west London.

place_437.name: Northern Ireland
place_437.description: Northern Ireland consists of six counties to the north-east of the island, not including the Republic of Ireland county, Donegal, to the west.

place_1415.name: Britain
place_1415.description: The isle of Britain, consisting of countries England, Wales, Scotland, and Northern Ireland.

place_878.name: United States
place_878.description: The U.S. is a country of 50 states covering a vast swath of North America, with Alaska in the northwest and Hawaii extending the nation’s presence into the Pacific Ocean.

place_021.name: Cornwall
place_021.description: Cornwall is a county in south-west England, birthplace of Humphry Davy.

place_025.name: Stockbridge
place_025.description: Stockbridge is a town in Hampshire.

place_121.name: England
place_121.description: England is a country that is part of the United Kingdom. It is located on the island of Great Britain, of which it covers approximately 62%, and over 100 smaller adjacent islands.

place_305.name: Bedfordshire
place_305.description: A county in the east of England. The county town is Bedford.

place_026.name: Loch Ness
place_026.description: Loch Ness is a large freshwater loch in the Scottish Highlands.

place_027.name: Hampshire
place_027.description: Hampshire is a county in southern England.

place_028.name: Berkshire
place_028.description: Berkshire is a county in south-east England.

place_029.name: Newbury, Berkshire
place_029.description: Newbury is a market town in the county of Berkshire, England.

place_031.name: Woburn
place_031.description: Davy mentions Priestley Bog and meadow near Woburn in Elements of Agricultural Chemistry p. 265.
